name: Philadelphia
fun_fact: Philadelphia invented the cheesesteak in 1930 when hot dog vendor Pat Olivieri threw beef on his grill. The famous rivalry between Pat's and Geno's (directly across the street from each other) has been going strong since 1966, both open 24/7. The city also invented the hoagie and is home to the Liberty Bell.

hero_dishes.name: Philly Cheesesteak
hero_dishes.description: Thinly sliced ribeye steak, melted cheese (Cheez Whiz, American, or provolone), and optional grilled onions on an Italian roll
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented in 1930 by Pat Olivieri at 9th & Wharton. A cab driver asked for one of Pat's beef sandwiches, and soon he had a following. Pat's has been family-owned for almost 90 years.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Pat's King of Steaks (invented it, chops the meat) vs Geno's Steaks (across the street, doesn't chop meat). Locals also swear by Jim's, Tony Luke's, John's Roast Pork, and Angelo's in Bella Vista.

hero_dishes.name: Hoagie
hero_dishes.description: Italian cold cuts, cheese, lettuce, tomato, onions, oil and vinegar on a long Italian roll
hero_dishes.origin_story: Also invented in Philadelphia during the early 20th century. The hoagie evolved alongside the cheesesteak, eventually creating the hoagie cheesesteak hybrid.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Both Pat's and Geno's serve Italian hoagies. Look for Sarcone's rolls - the locals' favorite.

hero_dishes.name: Roast Pork Sandwich
hero_dishes.description: Slow-roasted pork topped with sharp provolone and broccoli rabe on an Italian roll
hero_dishes.origin_story: Some Philly natives argue this is actually better than the cheesesteak. It's the local's secret favorite.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: John's Roast Pork, Tony Luke's, and Geno's all serve excellent versions

hero_dishes.name: Soft Pretzels
hero_dishes.description: Large, chewy pretzels with coarse salt, often served with yellow mustard
hero_dishes.origin_story: Philadelphia is famous for soft pretzels sold by street vendors throughout the city
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street carts throughout the city, especially near Independence Hall

signature_drinks.name: Yuengling Lager
signature_drinks.description: America's oldest brewery (founded 1829), based in nearby Pottsville, PA
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The default beer order in Philly - just say 'Lager' and they'll know you mean Yuengling

signature_drinks.name: Birch Beer
signature_drinks.description: Sweet, root beer-like soda made from birch bark
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: A regional specialty often found at cheesesteak shops and diners

food_culture_notes: How to order: 'wiz wit' = Cheez Whiz with onions, 'American witout' = American cheese without onions
Pat's chops the meat, Geno's doesn't - that's a key difference in the rivalry
Both Pat's and Geno's are open 24/7 and directly across from each other at 9th & Passyunk
Locals debate endlessly about the best cheesesteak - many say Jim's or Angelo's beat the famous two
Angelo's (opened 2019) uses Sarcone's seeded rolls and has already become a local favorite
The cheesesteak evolved into the hoagie cheesesteak, combining two Philly inventions

landmarks: Rocky Steps at Philadelphia Museum of Art
City Hall with 37-foot William Penn statue
Pat's and Geno's neon signs at 9th & Passyunk
atmosphere: Historic brick buildings and cobblestone streets
colors: Neon signs at Pat's and Geno's
unique_modern: Angelo's modern take on traditional cheesesteaks
Food hall culture at Reading Terminal Market
